Cantrips.Base:
Every wizard can cast a handful of cantrips each day. You don’t have to memorize or choose them beforehand, you just cast them on the fly.

Wizards can cast a number of cantrips equal to their Intelligence modifier each battle. Each cantrip takes a standard action to cast as a ranged spell.

Outside of battle, a wizard can cast about three to six cantrips every five minutes. The Cantrip Mastery talent speeds up cantrip casting.

At the adventurer tier (levels 1–4), cantrips with a standard duration last 10–60 minutes, plus 10 minutes per wizard level. The GM rolls and the wizard becomes aware that their cantrip is about to end a couple of minutes before it’s done.

At the champion tier (levels 5–7), most cantrips last 1–6 hours.

At the epic tier (levels 8–10), cantrips last between 2–12 hours.

Cyclic Spells.Base:
Spells that have a cyclic usage can always be cast at least once per battle, and are only expended in that battle if they are cast when the escalation die is 0 or odd.

If you cast a cyclic spell like color spray or rebuke when the escalation die is even, the spell is not expended and can still be cast later in the battle.

Overworld Advantage.Base: Wizardly magic taps into the power of the overworld. While a wizard is in the overworld, their daily spells become recharge 16+ after battle.

Ritual Magic.Base: Wizards can cast their spells as rituals.
Ritual Magic.Champion:
You can cast full rituals by using all your actions each round to focus on the ritual for 1d3 + 1 rounds.

As with standard rituals, your fast rituals are not meant to replace combat spells; they’re a means of acquiring and improvising wondrous magical effects rather than a means of inflicting damage and conditions.

Utility Spell.Base:
When you choose spells during a full heal-up, instead of taking a standard spell, you can choose to give up a spell slot to memorize the utility spell at the same level. When you take the utility spell, you gain access to a range of useful non-combat spells of the level you memorized it or below. You cast each utility spell at the level of the spell slot you gave up for it. You can give up multiple spell slots to take utility spell multiple times.

Choose from among the following utility spells:

1st level: disguise self, feather fall, hold portal
Level 3: arcane eye, levitate, message, speak with item
Level 5: wall of stone, water breathing
Level 7: scrying
Utility Spell.Adventurer: Each utility spell you take lets you cast two spells from the available options instead of one.
Utility Spell.Champion: As above, but you can cast three utility spells instead of one.

Abjuration.Base: Whenever you cast a daily wizard spell, you gain a +4 AC bonus until the end of your next turn.
Abjuration.Adventurer: The bonus also applies to your Physical Defense.
Abjuration.Champion: You gain 2d12 temporary hit points each time you cast a daily spell.
Abjuration.Epic: The bonus also applies to Mental Defense.

Cantrip Mastery.Base:
Cantrips are at-will spells for you. Unlike normal wizards, who use a standard action to cast a cantrip, you can cast a cantrip as a quick action.

To do something particularly cunning or surprising with one of your cantrips where the GM isn’t sure whether you could pull off that use of the spell, roll a normal save (11+) to cast the spell the way you envision it.

Additionally, you can expend a Level 3 spell slot or higher to choose one cantrip per spell slot you have given up and create a once-per-day related effect with it that is much greater, if you and your GM can agree on a cool effect that suits the cantrip.
Cantrip Mastery.Adventurer:
You can use cantrip-style versions of any wizard spell you have memorized. When you expend a spell, however, you can’t make cantrip-style use of it any more. The key is that none of these uses should be combat relevant or deal damage.

The Cantrip Mastery talent is more about enhancing roleplaying and less about combat usefulness.

Evocation.Base:
Once per battle, when you cast a spell that targets Physical Defense, before rolling for the number of targets or making the spell’s attack roll, you can expend your quick action to evoke the spell.

Hit or miss, you’ll max out the spell’s damage dice (except on a natural one, which deals no damage to the target and likely damages the caster in some manner).
Evocation.Champion: Whenever you evoke a spell, you can reroll one of the attack rolls if that natural roll was less than or equal to the escalation die. You must take the new result.

High Arcana.Base:
Your study of the highest orders of magic gives you options that lesser wizards cannot match: Memorization and a bonus spell: counter-magic.

Memorization: When you pick your spells, you can choose any daily wizard spell twice (instead of once). This doesn’t apply to spells that start as recharge spells. For example, at Level 7 when you have five Level 7 spells and four Level 5 spells, you could choose fireball twice as a Level 7 spell, or once as a Level 7 spell and once as a Level 5 spell. (Your Level 3 spell slot can’t be used for fireball because fireball starts as a Level 5 spell.)

Counter-magic.Trigger: A nearby creature you can see casts a spell.
Counter-magic.Target: The nearby creature casting a spell.
Counter-magic.Hit: The target’s spell is canceled, and the caster loses the action they were using for the spell. If the spell had a limited use, that use is expended if your natural attack roll is even.
Counter-magic.Champion: You can now cast counter-magic twice per battle.
Counter-magic.Epic: You can now cast counter-magic in reaction to a creature using any magical ability, not just casting a spell.

Polysyllabic Verbalizations.Base:
Rename each of your daily and recharge spells. Think up the most over-the-top and extravagant names you can muster. Since these alternate spells are so lengthy, they take an additional quick action to cast.

While the regular effects of the spells are the same as the more common versions, they have a small bonus effect appropriate to the situation.

The bonus effect is determined by the GM, or by a collaboration between the GM and the player. It should add to the storytelling power of the situation. The bonus effect should suit the name of the spell or the way it’s delivered, and shouldn’t precisely match up with what the spell normally accomplishes.

Wizard's Familiar.Base:
Your familiar is a tiny or small animal or creature that aids your magic and provides companionship. It also provides opportunities for improvisation between you and the GM.

Your familiar is as intelligent as a normal person. It can communicate with you and will stay close to you unless you’ve chosen abilities that let it roam. Your familiar is on your side but it’s not perfectly in your control.

If your familiar dies, it can come back to you the next time you get a full heal-up. (The method or story used is between you and the GM.) Alternatively, you can get a new familiar.

Familiars are useless in combat, except as indicated by their abilities. Ordinarily, they aren’t damaged by enemy attacks and spells unless the story calls for it.
Wizard's Familiar.Champion: Once per level, if your familiar is close to you, it can cast one of your spells as a free action on your initiative count, even if you have already expended the spell. The spell functions as if you had cast it.

Familiar Abilities.Agile: You gain a +2 bonus to Dexterity skill checks.
Familiar Abilities.Alert / Insightful: You gain a +2 bonus to Wisdom skill checks.
Familiar Abilities.Counter-bite: Each battle, if your familiar is close to you, it bites the first enemy that hits you with a melee attack after that attack, dealing 1d4 damage per level (no attack roll) to that enemy.
Familiar Abilities.Flight: Your familiar flies as well as a hawk. It doesn’t fly that often and usually sticks with you, but it can do so when its other abilities allow.
Familiar Abilities.Mimic: One battle per day, you gain the use of the racial power (without feats) of one nearby ally.
Familiar Abilities.Poisonous: Once per battle, when you hit an enemy engaged with you, you can add 5 ongoing poison damage per tier to the damage roll.
Familiar Abilities.Scout: Once per day, your familiar can separate itself from you and make a reconnaissance run of an area or location. Roll an easy skill check for the environment to get your familiar to scout unseen.
Familiar Abilities.Tough: You gain a +1 save bonus. Tough counts as two familiar abilities.
Familiar Abilities.Talkative: Your familiar can talk like a person (but the GM speaks for the familiar more than you do).

Disguise Self.Effect: This spell provides you with an effective magical disguise that lasts about ten minutes, making the skill check to avoid unmasking one step easier: easy if it would have been a normal task, normal if it would have been a hard task, and hard if it would have been a ridiculously hard task. The spell only affects your general appearance, not your size. It can be used to hide your features behind the generic features of another person or race. Using it to impersonate a specific creature makes it less effective as a disguise (-2 to -5 penalty).
Disguise Self.Level 5: The spell also provides smell; +2 bonus to any checks.
Disguise Self.Level 7: The spell also handles correct-sounding vocal patterns and rough mannerisms; +4 bonus to any checks.
Disguise Self.Level 9: You can now target an ally with the spell; you can also now use it on up to two creatures at once.

Feather Fall.Effect: When you cast this spell, it arrests your fall, letting you glide down the ground over a round or two.
Feather Fall.Level 3: You can now target a nearby ally with the spell.
Feather Fall.Level 5: You can now target up to two nearby creatures with the spell.
Feather Fall.Level 7: You can now target up to five nearby creatures with the spell.
Feather Fall.Level 9: You gain some control over where a target falls, like a quickly gliding feather.

Hold Portal.Effect: You cast this spell on a door. For ten minutes, adventurer-tier creatures can’t get through the door. Champion-tier creatures can batter it down; each attempt requires a DC 20 Intelligence skill check (including an applicable background) by the caster to resist the battering and keep the spell going. Epic-tier creatures can walk right through.
Hold Portal.Level 3: The spell now lasts for an hour. Adventurer-tier creatures are stymied. Champion-tier creatures can batter the door down or destroy it after three failed DC 20 skill checks by the spellcaster. Epic creatures notice that the now-busted door had magic on it.
Hold Portal.Level 5: Champion-tier creatures take a few minutes to force the door open. Epic creatures can force it open after one failed DC 25 skill check by the spellcaster.
Hold Portal.Level 7: Champion-tier creatures are stymied for up to an hour by the door. Epic tier creatures get through after three failed DC 25 skill checks by the spellcaster.
Hold Portal.Level 9: Champion-tier creatures can’t enter. Epic-tier creatures can’t get through for an hour.

Levitate.Effect: Until the end of the battle, you can use a move action to rise straight up into the air or descend straight down. The spell itself won’t move you horizontally. The up-or-down movement is about half as fast as your normal movement. While levitating, you take a –2 penalty to your attacks and are vulnerable to attacks against you.
Levitate.Level 5: You can now cast the spell on a nearby willing ally instead of yourself.
Levitate.Level 7: You can now cast the spell as a quick action, and the spell can now affect two targets.
Levitate.Level 9: The spell can now affect five targets.

Message.Effect: You send a one to two sentence message to another person you know and have touched in the last week. Sending a message to a person you can see is always easy. Sending a message to a person you can’t see requires a skill check using Intelligence against the highest-tier environment that you or the sender are occupying.
Message.Level 3: Across half a city, at most.
Message.Level 5: Across the entire city and a bit into the countryside.
Message.Level 7: Between cities near to each other.
Message.Level 9: From any city to any other city, or across a sea.

Speak with Item.Effect: Speak briefly, mind-to-mind, with a magic item you are touching that is owned by you or one of your allies. The item’s owner gets a free power recharge roll if that item’s power has been expended.
Speak with Item.Level 5: You no longer need to be touching the item; it only has to be nearby.
Speak with Item.Level 7: The item’s owner gains a +2 bonus to the item recharge roll.
Speak with Item.Level 9: If the item recharge roll fails, you keep this spell, but the item won’t talk to you until after your next full heal-up.

Water Breathing.Effect: You can breathe underwater for the rest of the battle (or about five minutes). You become aware a couple of rounds ahead of when the magic of the spell is about to end.
Water Breathing.Level 7: You and 1d4 + 2 nearby allies can breathe underwater this battle.
Water Breathing.Level 9: The spell affects you and 1d6 + 2 nearby allies for 4d6 hours.

Scrying.Effect: You can use this spell to get information you shouldn’t be able to get, peering in on other people’s lives for a short period of time, usually no more than ten minutes at a time. Some areas may be warded at the GM’s discretion. You must have touched the person you wish to spy on in the last month, or, at Level 9, within the last year.
Scrying.Level 9: You can spy on the person even if you haven’t touched them in the last year. The scrying effect lasts for up to 1 hour.

Alarm.Effect: The cantrip creates a minor watch-sprite that can be instructed to scream if someone comes through an area or touches an object. Watch-sprites are notoriously stupid and sleepy, but with the right talking-to they might stay focused for the duration of the spell. At higher levels, the spell might summon little fanged spirits buzzing back and forth serving as both visual and actual deterrents.

Arcane Mark.Effect: The cantrip creates a magical sigil on an object or person. These sigils are usually plain to see, though a deliberately invisible mark can be made. It takes a difficult perception or magic check to notice.

Ghost Sound.Effect: This spell creates false noises emanating from somewhere nearby. The effect is like an exceptionally good version of throwing your voice, if your voice could create a wide variety of sounds. Attempted distractions with the cantrip are DC 15 challenges in adventurer environments, higher as you move into champion and epic environments. If someone is using ghost sound against the PCs, a Wisdom-based skill check can identify the sound as a magical fake.

Knock.Effect: This cantrip summons a magical servitor three to four times as big as your closed fist that swarms around the door and attempts to punch or push it open (depending on whether you want to be quiet or announce your presence). Success is determined with an Intelligence check against the environment’s DC using an appropriate magical background. This cantrip does nothing to avoid any traps that might exist.

Light.Effect: This cantrip creates a fairly wide and consistent field of light, up to 30 feet in diameter, though it isn’t bright enough to dazzle.

Mage Hand.Effect: This cantrip creates a small telekinetic effect that lasts a round at most. At best it’s about half as strong as the wizard’s own strongest hand. At worst it’s half as strong as the wizard when they’re weak from a bad fever.

Mending.Effect: This cantrip summons a variety of tiny (hand-sized and smaller) magical sprites who swarm over a chosen broken object attempting to mend it (over the course of 1–6 rounds). Small-scale repairs like torn wineskins, muddy clothing, a broken handgrip on a sword, and similar repairs that anyone could fix with two to four hours of devoted work gets handled in seconds. More elaborate repairs to complicated objects might require an Intelligence check, or at the GM’s discretion could only be possible if the wizard has taken the Cantrip Mastery talent.

Prestidigitation.Effect: This cantrip produces magic tricks and small illusions. One casting usually gives you a minute of fun. The magic has nowhere near as much real world force as mage hand.

Spark.Effect: This is a minor fire creation spell, enough to light a pipe, or a campfire, or even a page or two of an unprotected spellbook. It doesn’t work against living beings or against things that couldn’t easily be set on fire with a few seconds of steady application of a candle. The target of the spark has to be nearby and in sight.

Acid Arrow.Target: One nearby or far away creature
Acid Arrow.Hit: 4d10 acid damage, and 5 ongoing acid damage.
Acid Arrow.Miss: 5 ongoing acid damage, and you regain the spell during your next quick rest.
Acid Arrow.Level 3: 5d10 damage, and 10 ongoing damage; 10 ongoing on a miss.
Acid Arrow.Level 5: 8d10 damage, and 15 ongoing damage; 15 ongoing on a miss.
Acid Arrow.Level 7: 3d4 x 10 damage, and 25 ongoing damage; 25 ongoing on a miss.
Acid Arrow.Level 9: 5d4 x 10 damage, and 40 ongoing damage; 40 ongoing on a miss.

Blur.Effect: For the rest of the battle (or for five minutes), attacks against the target miss 20% of the time.
Blur.Level 3: The spell is now a quick action to cast.
Blur.Level 7: Miss 30% of the time, and you can now target 1d2 creatures with the spell.
Blur.Level 9: Miss 30% of the time, and you can now target two creatures with the spell.

Charm Person.Target: One nearby creature with 40 hp or fewer
Charm Person.Special: This spell cannot be cast during combat or on a target that has rolled initiative to fight.
Charm Person.Hit: The target believes you are their friend until you or your allies take hostile action against them. (Attacking their normal allies is okay.) If you or your allies attack the target or order the target to attack its normal allies, the target can roll a normal save to break the charm effect during its turn each round.
Charm Person.Miss: On a miss, the spell is not detectable by most others unless you miss by 4+ or roll a natural 1, in which case the target and its allies know what you tried to do and will usually be angry about it.

Color Spray.Frequency: Cyclic (cast once per battle OR at-will when the escalation die is even)
Color Spray.Hit: 2d8 psychic damage, and if the target has 10 hp or fewer after the damage, it is weakened until the end of your next turn.
Color Spray.Adventurer: Increase the hit point threshold of the weakened effect by 5 hp.
Color Spray.Champion: On a miss, the spell deals damage equal to your level.
Color Spray.Epic: The spell now targets 1d4 + 1 nearby enemies in a group.

Magic Missile.Target: One nearby or far away enemy
Magic Missile.Adventurer: You can choose two targets; roll half the damage dice for one missile and half the damage dice for the other, then assign one set of damage dice to each of the two targets.
Magic Missile.Champion: Roll a d20 when you use the spell; if you roll a natural 20, the magic missile crits and deals double damage. (Rolling a 1 is not a fumble; this roll checks only to see if you can crit.)
Magic Missile.Epic: The 7th and Level 9 versions of the spell now use d8s as damage dice.

Ray of Frost.Adventurer: When your ray of frost attack roll is a natural even hit, if the target is staggered after taking the damage, it is also dazed until the end of your next turn.
Ray of Frost.Champion: The target of the spell can also be far away.
Ray of Frost.Epic: When you cast the spell you can change the damage type to lightning or negative energy.

Shield.Effect: The attacker must reroll the attack. You must accept the new result.
Shield.Level 3: You gain a +2 AC bonus against the rerolled attack.
Shield.Level 5: You can also use the spell against attacks that target your Physical Defense; replace references to AC with PD.
Shield.Level 7: The bonus to AC/PD on the rerolled attack increases to +4.
Shield.Level 9: The bonus to AC/PD on the rerolled attack increases to +6.
Shield.Adventurer: You can now choose either of the attack rolls, in case the second one crits or is otherwise bad for you.
Shield.Champion: Recharge roll after battle is now 6+.
Shield.Epic: Hit or miss, you take only half damage from any attack you use shield against.

Shocking Grasp.Hit: 1d4 lightning damage, and the target pops free from you.
Shocking Grasp.Miss: You take damage equal to the target’s level from botched feedback.
Shocking Grasp.Adventurer: The spell now requires only a quick action to cast (once per round).
Shocking Grasp.Champion: Once per battle, when you hit the target of the spell, you can also daze it until the end of your next turn.
Shocking Grasp.Epic: The damage dice of the spell increase to d8s.

Confusion.Target: One nearby enemy with 100 hp or fewer
Confusion.Miss: If you miss all targets, you regain this spell during your next quick rest.
Confusion.Level 5: Target with 160 hp or fewer, and the target can be far away.
Confusion.Level 7: Target with 250 hp or fewer, or two targets each with 125 hp or fewer.
Confusion.Level 9: Target with 500 hp or fewer, or two targets each with 250 hp or fewer.
Confusion.Adventurer: On a miss against all targets with this spell, you can choose to daze those targets (save ends). If you do, you do not regain the spell.
Confusion.Champion: Each failed save against the spell deals 6d10 psychic damage to the target.
Confusion.Epic: The save against confused is now a difficult save (16+).

Crescendo.Target: One or more enemies engaged with you (but see below)
Crescendo.Special: You can choose more than one target for this spell, but you take a –2 penalty when attacking two targets, a –3 penalty for three targets, and so on.
Crescendo.Hit: 4d6 thunder damage, and the target pops free from you.

Force Salvo.Target: One or more nearby or far away enemies (see below)
Force Salvo.Special: The spell creates a number of force bolts equal to 1 + your Intelligence modifier. You must target a different creature with each bolt; any extras can’t be used.
Force Salvo.Adventurer: You can now target a specific creature with more than one bolt. Once you hit that target, you must target a different creature, and so on. (Roll your attack after each bolt before picking a target for the next bolt.)
Force Salvo.Champion: On a miss, a bolt now deals miss damage equal to your level.
Force Salvo.Epic: Increase the number of bolts by 1.

Hold Monster.Target: One nearby enemy with 60 hp or fewer
Hold Monster.Hit: The target cannot move or use move actions (hard save ends, 16+).
Hold Monster.Miss: The target is dazed until the end of your next turn.
Hold Monster.Adventurer: If the spell misses all targets, you regain the spell during your next quick rest.
Hold Monster.Champion: The spell can target up to 2 nearby enemies whose total hit points don’t exceed the limit.

Lightning Bolt.Target: 1d3 + 1 nearby enemies in a group or in a (rough) line
Lightning Bolt.Champion: A natural even hit also deals 10 ongoing lightning damage.
Lightning Bolt.Epic: A natural even hit now deals 20 ongoing lightning damage (hard save ends, 16+).

Rebuke.Frequency: Cyclic (once per battle OR at-will when the escalation die is even)
Rebuke.Target: One nearby enemy with 100 hp or fewer
Rebuke.Hit: The target is hampered (only makes basic attacks) until the end of your next turn.
Rebuke.Adventurer: When you roll a natural even hit with the spell, you also deal psychic damage equal to double your level to the target.
Rebuke.Champion: When you hit the target with the spell, you also daze it until the end of your next turn.
Rebuke.Epic: When you roll a natural even miss against the target, you daze it until the end of your next turn.

Sleep.Target: Before making the attack, roll 3d20 + 45 to determine the maximum number of hit points of enemies you can target with the spell. The spell can affect multiple enemies. You must target nearby enemies with the current lowest hit points first, and you don’t get to choose the exact targets (except in the case of ties). If adding a creature would exceed the spell’s hit point maximum, that enemy can’t be a target.
Sleep.Hit: The target falls unconscious (hard save ends, 16+; it also ends if the target takes 10+ damage).
Sleep.Miss: The target is dazed until the end of your next turn.

Teleport Shield.Target: Always: For the rest of the battle, once per round when an enemy moves to engage you, you can make the following attack against it as a free action before it has the chance to attack in melee.
Teleport Shield.Hit: Teleport the enemy somewhere nearby you can see. You can place them in combat with one of your allies, but you can’t place them in a dangerous location. (It’s a defensive tool).
Teleport Shield.Level 5: The teleported enemy also takes 4d10 damage.
Teleport Shield.Champion: When your teleport shield attack misses, the spell’s attack is not expended that round.
Teleport Shield.Epic: You can now teleport the enemy somewhere far away that you can see; other restrictions still apply.

Denial.Hit: 9d10 psychic damage, and the target is hampered until the end of your next turn.
Denial.Champion: When you roll a natural even miss with the spell, the target is also hampered until the end of your next turn.
Denial.Epic: Increase the number of targets to 1d4 + 1.

Dimension Door.Effect: You teleport somewhere nearby that you can see.
Dimension Door.Level 7: Your destination can now be far away, but not so far that it is out of range of enemy attacks that can hit far away targets.
Dimension Door.Level 9: You can take one ally who is next to you along with you as you teleport.

Fireball.Special: When you cast this spell, you can choose to cast it recklessly.
Fireball.Target: 1d3 nearby enemies in a group. If you cast recklessly, you can target 1d3 additional enemies, but then your allies engaged with the target may also take damage (see below).
Fireball.Miss: Half damage. Your allies engaged with the target take one-fourth damage.
Fireball.Champion: Casting the spell recklessly increases the number of additional targets to 1d4 instead of 1d3.
Fireball.Epic: Increase the number of targets to 1d3 + 1 instead of 1d3.

Invisibility.Effect: Until the end of the battle (or for five minutes out of combat), the target becomes invisible until it attacks or uses some ridiculously flashy action.
Invisibility.Special: High Arcana: The duration out of combat is 1 hour instead.
Invisibility.Level 7: You can now target 1d3 nearby allies (including you) with the spell.
Invisibility.Level 9: Creatures made invisible by the spell have a 25% chance of remaining invisible the first time (and first time only) they attack or get flashy.

Blink.Effect: For the rest of the battle (or for five minutes), the target gains resist damage 16+. Enemies who can see invisible creatures ignore this resistance. Whenever the target uses a move action, there is a 50% chance that it can teleport somewhere nearby instead of physically moving.

Flight.Effect: The target can fly until the end of the battle (or for five minutes). Your speed doesn’t increase appreciably but you can move in three-dimensions.
Flight.Level 9: When you cast the spell, you can choose one: the effect lasts for an hour OR you can target 1d4 + 1 creatures for the normal duration.

Haste.Effect: On the target’s next turn (not this one, if you cast it on yourself), the target gains an additional standard action. In addition, at the start of each of the target’s turns this battle, if the escalation die is even, roll a d20 and add the escalation die; on a 16+, the target gains an additional standard action that turn.
Haste.Level 9: The roll for additional standard actions is now 11+ instead of 16+.

Invisibility Purge.Target: Any nearby enemies who are invisible, whether you know they are there or not
Invisibility Purge.Effect: The target turns visible and cannot become invisible again this battle.
Invisibility Purge.Level 9: The spell also affects far away targets that you could normally see.

Overcome Resistance.Target: 1d3 nearby allies (including yourself, if you wish)
Overcome Resistance.Effect: Until the end of the battle, the target ignores the resistance power of any creature it targets with an attack.
Overcome Resistance.Level 9: You can now target 1d4 nearby allies with the spell.

Transfer Enchantment.Special: You or an ally you are next to must be suffering from a condition caused by an enemy for you to cast this spell.
Transfer Enchantment.Hit: 2d6 x 10 psychic damage, and you can transfer one condition caused by your enemies from you or the ally you are next to over to the target. If timing is required, interpret the transferred condition as if you had caused it with this spell.
Transfer Enchantment.Level 9: 2d10 x 10 damage; if the spell misses, you regain it during your next quick rest.

Disintegrate.Hit: 4d8 x 10 damage, and the target is vulnerable (hard save ends, 16+). In addition, if the target drops to 0 hp from this attack, or drops to 0 hp before it saves against the vulnerable effect of this attack, it is gone, dusted, nothing remaining.
Disintegrate.Epic: You can now target a far away creature with the spell.

Meteor Swarm.Special: You summon a meteor swarm. If you’re underground, you get the ur-dark stalactite equivalent! Nothing more happens this round, but roll 1d3 + 1 to determine how many meteors you have summoned. At the start of your next turn, even if you are unconscious or dead or have left the area, the meteors arrive one per turn at the start of each of your turns and slam into the combat area.
Meteor Swarm.Target: You can make an attack with each meteor against 1d4 enemies in a group. Alternatively, use the spell to level an area with high impact property damage.
Meteor Swarm.Hit: 4d4 x 10 damage of the energy type of your choice (cold, fire, lightning). Any allies engaged with the enemies you are targeting take one-fourth damage from each meteor that impacts the area.
Meteor Swarm.Epic: Each meteor now deals 5d4 x 10 damage.

Teleport.Effect: You and up to 4 allies next to you can teleport to any location in the world, underworld, or overworld that you have previously visited. When you teleport, roll a d20. If you roll a 1, you miss your desired location and arrive somewhere else altogether. Otherwise, you and your allies arrive at the desired location at the start of your next turn. Any effects of spells or items cast before teleporting are dispelled and no longer function on arrival.
Teleport.Epic: Your allies don’t need to be next to you before you cast the spell, just nearby. Alternately, if they are all next to you when you cast the spell, you can teleport to a location known to one of your allies.
